docs.lead_paragraph: Representative Charlie Norwood, a leader of the six-year campaign for legislation defining patients' rights, said today that the White House had expressed a new willingness to support a compromise letting patients sue health insurers for medical injuries caused by substandard care. Mr. Norwood said he and the White House favored the proposal, which would allow patients to recover up to $4 million for pain and suffering and other noneconomic damages resulting from serious injuries.

headline.main: Bush Is Said to Be Set to Back Patients' Bill

docs.abstract: Rep Charlie Norwood, a leader of six-year campaign for legislation defining patients' rights, says White House has expressed new willingness to support compromise that would let patients sue health maintenance organizations and other health insurers for medical injuries caused by substandard care (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The American Lung Association and the American Thoracic Society announced yesterday that they were moving their national headquarters from Midtown Manhattan to 61 Broadway, near Wall Street about four blocks from ground zero. The 38,000 square feet of space the two nonprofit organizations will occupy is a tiny fraction of the 15.4 million square feet of downtown office space that sits vacant, according to TenantWise.com, a real estate company. But news that any commercial tenant was moving to a section of the city still reeling from the attack on the World Trade Center and corporate defections was cause for celebration by city and state officials and landlords.
docs.abstract: American Lung Assn and American Thoracic Society move their national headquarters from Midtown Manhattan to 61 Broadway, near Wall Street (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In a sign that the job market in the United States might be picking up, the number of workers filing first-time claims for state unemployment benefits fell last week to the lowest level in more than a year, the Labor Department reported today. Initial jobless claims, which offer an early glimpse into the health of the labor market, dropped 32,000 last week, to 383,000, from a revised 415,000 the previous week, the report said.

headline.main: Initial Claims for Jobless Benefits Decline Sharply

docs.abstract: Number of US workers filing first-time claims for state unemployment benefits falls for week to 383,000, lowest level in more than year; Wall Street analysts expected only slight decline (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Hershey Foods Corporation and negotiators for 2,700 striking factory workers reached a tentative agreement tonight that could end a 42-day strike, a company official said. John Long, the company's vice president for corporate communications, said an agreement was reached in a late-night meeting at the Hershey Hotel.

headline.main: Temporary Agreement Reached In Contract Dispute at Hershey

docs.lead_paragraph: Under intense pressure from health care lobbyists, House Republicans say they have decided to increase Medicare payments to doctors, hospitals and health maintenance organizations, reducing the amount of money available to provide prescription drug benefits to the elderly. Lobbyists for the health care industry have endorsed the Republican package, which is tentatively scheduled for a vote on the House floor this month. But advocates for the elderly have reserved judgment, saying some older people will not sign up for the drug plan unless the benefits are more generous.

headline.main: House Republican Plan Would Increase Medicare Payments to Providers

docs.abstract: House Republicans decide to increase Medicare payments to doctors, hospitals and health maintenance organizations, reducing the amount of money available to provide prescription drug benefits to elderly; lobbyists for health care industry endorse package, but advocates for elderly are reserving judgment; Senate could go along with House in raising Medicare payments to doctors and hospitals, but is likely to insist on more generous drug benefits (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Health insurers are demanding premium increases of more than 20 percent on average for next year, a sharp increase from earlier forecasts, a national survey reported yesterday. Indications of similar increases were reported by employer groups across the country as many companies opened negotiations with health insurers on rates for 2003. Health maintenance organizations are demanding rate increases averaging 22 percent, according to the survey, in which 140 employers were contacted by Hewitt Health Resource, an online unit of Hewitt Associates, a benefits consulting firm. That follows increases averaging 15.3 percent in 2002, Hewitt said.

headline.main: Health Insurers Are Seeking 20% Rate Rise

docs.abstract: Hewitt Health Resource survey finds health maintenance organizations are demanding average premium increases of 22 percent from employers for 2003, after raising rates average of 15.3 percent in 2002; experts warn increases could be higher for small businesses (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: If you want to get a rise out of the Democrats who lead the New York State Assembly, ask about the important women's health care bill that is languishing in Albany with time running out on the legislative session. To further annoy them, point out that it was the Republican-led State Senate that boldly passed the measure in February, despite criticism from the Roman Catholic Church, and that it is the Democrats -- longtime champions of women's health -- who stand in the way. The breakthrough bill would require insurance plans to cover screening for osteoporosis, cervical and breast cancer -- as well as contraceptives for women. The Democrats claim that politics accounted for the Republican conversion on the issue, and indeed it did. The Senate majority leader, Joseph Bruno, had long insisted that any bill include a broad exemption allowing employers to opt out of providing contraceptive coverage. He settled for a much narrower provision to help the Republican candidate in a close State Senate election on Manhattan's East Side in which Republican intransigence on the bill became a big issue. But that saga is ancient history. The Democratic candidate won the special election anyway, and further delay could shut a legislative window that may not open again soon.
docs.abstract: Editorial calls on New York State Legislature to approve women's health care bill

docs.lead_paragraph: American Ballet Theater's opening night at the Metropolitan Opera House last month was the quintessence of glitter and grace. The black-tie audience shouted bravos throughout the performance, the critical notices that followed were glowing, and the mood at the dinner afterward was festive and upbeat. Was the good feeling symbolic of a turnaround at what, along with the New York City Ballet, has long been considered one of the country's two great classical dance companies? After a financially trying two years in which productions were canceled, staff members quit, donors defected and the executive director was forced to resign, could Ballet Theater be heading for fiscal and spiritual health?

headline.main: Ballet Theater: Signs of Promise Amid Struggle

docs.abstract: Article assesses American Ballet Theater as its finances slowly improve and it grapples to regain spiritual health; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: LAST year, I wrote about people who want to retire before they turn 65 -- meaning that they don't yet qualify for Medicare -- but have no retiree health care benefits from their employers. A reader wrote to tell me that I had certainly identified a problem but had been a little short in specific solutions, other than paying for private insurance, if you can get it.

headline.main: In Search of a Bridge to Medicare

docs.abstract: Fred Brock Seniority column on health insurance options for Americans who want to retire before they are 65 and have retiree health care benefits from their employer to tide them over until Medicare kicks in (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The essay entitled ''What Malpractice Insurance Crisis?'' doesn't surprise me, as it comes from a malpractice trial lawyer who perhaps like his colleagues has reaped the benefits of large malpractice awards. Why wouldn't he write an essay of this nature since his own livelihood might be threatened by the prospect of tort reform? The trial lawyers of this country through multimillion-dollar settlements have been more than able to finance political action groups and lobbyists to make sure that tort reform is stifled. They have been successful in almost every state except California, where limits were placed and liability insurance premiums have been stable.

headline.main: Malpractice Insurance Is Indeed in Crisis

docs.abstract: Dr John D Frattarola letter on May 26 Soapbox essay holds malpractice insurance crisis in New Jersey is real
